results.cohortDescription: Distribution of total patient counts across networked institutions.

explorePage.tourSearchIntro: PIC-SURE Search allows you to search for variable level data.
explorePage.queryErrorText: There was an error with your query. If this persists, please contact you PIC-SURE admin.
explorePage.filterErrorText: There was an error when adding the filter to the query. Please remove your most recent filter and try again. If this error persists, please contact us. We will respond to your request as soon as we can.
explorePage.analysisExportText: To export data and start your analysis, use the following code to connect to PIC-SURE and save the dataframe or download the file. Note that you will need your personal access token to complete the connection to PIC-SURE with code.
explorePage.confirmDownloadTitle: Are you sure you want to download data?
explorePage.confirmDownloadMessage: This action will download the data to your local machine. Are you sure you want to proceed?

codeBlocks.PythonExport:
# Requires python 3.7 or later
import sys
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
!{sys.executable} -m pip install --upgrade --force-reinstall git+https://github.com/hms-dbmi/pic-sure-python-adapter-hpds.git
!{sys.executable} -m pip install --upgrade --force-reinstall git+https://github.com/hms-dbmi/pic-sure-python-client.git

import PicSureHpdsLib
import PicSureClient

PICSURE_network_URL = "{{PICSURE_NETWORK_URL}}"

token_file = "token.txt"
with open(token_file, "r") as f:
		my_token = f.read()

connection = PicSureClient.Client.connect(url = PICSURE_network_URL, token = my_token)

queryID = "{{queryId}}"

results = resource.retrieveQueryResults(queryID)
from io import StringIO
df_UI = pd.read_csv(StringIO(results), low_memory=False)
codeBlocks.RExport:
# Requires R 3.4 or later
install.packages("devtools")

devtools::install_github("hms-dbmi/pic-sure-r-adapter-hpds", ref="main", force=T, quiet=FALSE)
library(dplyr)

PICSURE_network_URL = "{{PICSURE_NETWORK_URL}}"
token_file <- "token.txt"
token <- scan(token_file, what = "character")
session <- picsure::bdc.initializeSession(PICSURE_network_URL, token)
session <- picsure::bdc.setResource(session = session)

queryID <- "{{queryId}}"

results <- picsure::getResultByQueryUUID(session, queryID)

codeBlocks.RAPI:
# Requires R 3.4 or later
install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("hms-dbmi/pic-sure-r-adapter-hpds", ref="main", force=T, quiet=FALSE)
library(dplyr)

PICSURE_network_URL = "{{PICSURE_NETWORK_URL}}"
token_file <- "token.txt"
token <- scan(token_file, what = "character")
session <- picsure::bdc.initializeSession(PICSURE_network_URL, token)
session <- picsure::bdc.setResource(session = session)

goTo.instructions: Copy your personal access token and save as a text file called "token.txt" in the same working directory to execute the code above.

actions.title: Explore
actions.description: Explore data, apply filters, and build cohorts

actions.title: Prepare for Analysis
actions.description: Use the PIC-SURE API to prepare data for analysis

cards.body: Step-by-step instructions to get started using the PIC-SURE API

instructions.connection: To connect to the PIC-SURE Application Programming Interface (API), you will need your personal access token. Copy your token and save as a text file called "token.txt" in the working directory of your chosen analysis workspace.
instructions.execution: To start your analysis, copy and execute the following code in your preferred analysis environment to connect to the PIC-SURE API. Note that you will need your personal access token to complete the connection.

analysis.introduction:
Introduction to Service Workbench

After you have identified patients for research using the Cohort Builder, found collaborators from other GIC sites, submitted the RedCap Request Form for accessing data, and received approval from each site’s Sample and Data Access Committee (SDAC), you are ready to begin analysis. You can access and analyze patient-level data using Service Workbench.

Service Workbench (SWB) is an open-source cloud computing platform from Amazon Web Services (AWS). This platform provides secure, repeatable, and federated control of access to data, tooling, and computing power. This allows you to easily access any cloud workspace from a catalog of pre-configured environments, leverage all AWS AI/ML and native security controls, and collaborate with researchers from other sites through a simple web application.
analysis.access:
Accessing Service Workbench

First, ensure that you are connected to your institution’s virtual private network (VPN). Then, you can navigate to the GIC Service Workbench and log in with your institutional email address.

Go to GIC Service Workbench

For additional information about Service Workbench and setting up your computing workspace, you can refer to the Genomic Information Commons documentation.
analysis.examples:
Example Code and Training Videos

Publicly available example code has been created to help you get started on your analysis, available on the Access to Data and Compute using Service Workbench GitHub repository, with example notebooks called “Investigating EHR data in PIC-SURE” in R and Python; for instructions on importing these into Service Workbench, refer to the GIC Service Workbench documentation.

There are also tutorial videos that describe each step in the notebooks in more detail. You can find these here:

  • Brief introduction to EHR data from PIC-SURE in R
  • Brief introduction to EHR data from PIC-SURE in Python
  • Extended examples for EHR data from PIC-SURE in R
  • Extended examples for EHR data from PIC-SURE in Python

collaboratePage.introduction:
Expand Access with Collaborators

Once you have defined your patient cohort using the Cohort Builder (link to page here), you will see which sites have data that match these criteria. To gain access to patient-level data from other GIC network institutions, the Principal Investigator (PI) must identify and engage co-PIs at the other site.

For example, a researcher from Boston Children's Hospital (BCH) created a cohort and would like to collaborate with the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP), which has patients that match their research criteria. The BCH PI would find a collaborating PI at CHOP to access the CHOP patient-level data.
collaboratePage.findCollaborators:
Resources to Find Collaborators

You can search for collaborators from the GIC network using the associated faculty listings:

  • Boston Children's Hospital / Harvard Medical School
  • Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center
  • Children's Hospital of Philadelphia
  • St. Louis Children's Hospital / Washington University at St. Louis
  • University of Pittsburgh Medical Center
  • Le Bonheur Children's Hospital at the University of Tennessee Health Science Center

Additionally, you can email GIC-contact@chip.org for assistance in identifying a collaborator.

datasetRequestPage.searchIntro: The Dataset ID should be provided by the researcher in the RedCap Request Form. After the Sample and Data Access Committee (SDAC) has approved the request, the Data Admin can send the data to the designated S3 bucket to enable the researcher to access and analyze the data using Service Workbench.

genomicFilter.frequency: The variant allele frequency in gnomAD combined population as discrete text categories. Possible values: Novel (variant not in gnomAD database), Rare (variant frequency less than 1%), Common (variant frequency greater than or equal to 1%).
genomicFilter.consequence: A standardized term from the Sequence Ontology (http://www.sequenceontology.org) to describe the calculated consequence of a variant. The severity for the calculated consequence of a variant on a gene has possible values HIGH (frameshift, splice disrupting, or truncating variants), MEDIUM (non-frameshift insertions or deletions, variants altering protein sequencing without affecting its length) or LOW (other coding variants including synonymous variants).
